--- title: "Excel first steps" categories: [excel, beginner, Excel for beginners] execute: freeze: auto echo: false --- This session is part of our Excel for beginners course. That's a series of six linked sessions, delivered on Teams, that give an introduction to Excel for people working in health and social care. The sessions are: + [Excel first steps](excel_first_steps.qmd) (this session) + [Tidy data in Excel](tidy_data_in_excel.qmd) + [References and names in Excel](references_and_names_in_excel.qmd) + [Excel formatting](excel_formatting.qmd) + [Excel tables](excel_tables.qmd) + [Excel formulas](excel_formulas.qmd) Together, they aim to help you develop an appropriate set of Excel skills to help your work. This session covers a general overview of our beginner's skill tree: ![KIND Excel beginner's skill tree](images/clipboard-3454618035.png){width="100%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="left"} ## Previous attendees have said... - 109 previous attendees have left feedback - 99% would recommend this session to a colleague - 95% said that this session was pitched correctly ![](excel_first_steps_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){fig-align='left' width=288} :::{.callout-note} ### Three random comments from previous attendees - Session was very informative and useful, it will be great to build up excel skills over the next few weeks - Very informative with simple easy steps to follow. - Engaging and informative! ::: ::: ## A brief overview of Excel ![Excel might be the cement of the universe](images/clipboard-965547330.png){width="60%"} - one of the oldest, and most widely used, pieces of desktop software - ubiquitous in business, finance, health and social care... - proprietary, closed-source, paid-for - many versions ## But Excel is badly used, on the whole + [PHE lost 16k COVID19+ results](https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2020/oct/05/how-excel-may-have-caused-loss-of-16000-covid-tests-in-england) + [MI5 bugged 134 people they didn't mean to](https://www.theguardian.com/government-computing-network/2011/jul/01/mi5-data-collection-errors) + [JP Morgan 2012](https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomgroenfeldt/2013/02/19/solutions-to-spreadsheet-risk-post-jpms-london-whale/) had a manually-updated spreadsheet - divided by sum, rather than average - massive losses, $2 - $6 billion?? ## And most of us fall into Excel work... + most of us haven't had any data training + e.g. in KIND network (which is a very techy group) 75% didn't have a formal qualification + and the responsibility for doing that data work well falls on many of us + data work has become more prominent in lots of jobs + but good data work is really important... ## Good data helps... - answering which/when questions - seeing effects of changes - comparing different areas - looking at services over time - ... ## One word of warning before the practical part - there are lots of versions of Excel - they all work slightly differently - please don't panic if what you see looks slightly different from what I'm showing you - please ask if you're not happy/confident! ## Opening Excel (desktop) + find Excel in your Windows Start menu
![opening Excel on the Desktop](images/clipboard-1394052793.png) + you'll need to create a new blank workbook
![Create a new blank workbook](images/clipboard-2150015829.png){height="200"} ## Opening Excel (web) + usually at [https://www.office.com/launch/excel](https://www.office.com/launch/excel) + you'll need to create a new blank workbook
![Create a new blank workbook](images/clipboard-3067626588.png) ## Interface ![Excel interface](images/interface.png){width="90%"} ## Central idea - pieces of data are stored in cells - one value, one cell - cells are arranged into rows and columns
![cells are arranged in rows and columns](images/clipboard-1879510795.png){width="60%"} - arranging data like this allows us to analyse it - it's not just *Word on a grid* ## Save, close, open ![File menu](images/clipboard-3187630465.png){height="40%"} ![Save as](images/clipboard-1979369937.png){height="40%"} - save your new workbook - close it - re-open it (possibly from recent files) ## References - every cell in Excel has a **reference** - like its address - references look like this: `E7`
![example references](images/cols.png){height="250"} - `E` refers to a vertical column - `7` to a horizontal row ## Data entry - let's add some data... - we can type into the cells
![add data by typing into cells](images/clipboard-1771455666.png) - that data appears in the formula bar too ## An example: school holidays - Here are some [school holiday dates](https://www.scotborders.gov.uk/schools-learning/term-holiday-closure-dates/2) - make three headings in row 1: `name`, `start_date`, `end_date`
![add three headings in row 1](images/clipboard-1395187747.png) ## Values - let's add some values from the [school holiday dates](https://www.scotborders.gov.uk/schools-learning/term-holiday-closure-dates/2) - name of holiday - start date - end date - dates usually go `DD/MM/YYYY` - as we'll see, Excel does lots of helping when we enter dates... - ...ðŸ˜± - we'll only need a few rows of data ::: notes name start_date end_date Mid-term holidays 14/10/2024 18/10/2024 In service day 21/10/2024 21/10/2024 St Andrew's Day 02/12/2024 02/12/2024 ::: ## Tidy data - keep things consistent - spelling, case, formats, etc - one piece of data per cell - one instance per row (one school holiday per row) - one variable per column (a column of names, one of start dates...) ## Tables - we can convert this group of cells into a proper **table** - click in one of your cells of data
![Click a cell in your data](images/clipboard-1117112977.png) - `Insert` \> `Table` (or `Ctrl` + `T`)
![Convert to table](images/clipboard-166790706.png) - click `OK`
![](images/clipboard-77557231.png) ## Lots of new things to see ![Table features](images/clipboard-1614882971.png) ## Autofill - we'll add a formula to calculate how long our holidays are - add a new column called `days` - paste `= 1 + (C2 - B2)` into the first cell of that new column - and look out for our session on formulas... - double-click the green fill handle to fill the rest of the column
![fill handle](images/clipboard-1731283483.png) ## Formatting - we can change the way that our spreadsheet looks - we can also change the way our values look ## Cell formatting - some examples
![Formatting area](images/clipboard-4175540765.png) - highlighting - bold - borders ## Number formatting - our dates are **number formatted** - Excel dates are actually numbers (like `45583`) formatted to look like dates - 1900 dates! - percentages, Â£, ... ## Conditional formatting - we can also format based on values
![Conditional formatting](images/clipboard-3358194074.png) - take care though - this can be both ugly, and inaccessible
